name: Grigsu Haldo
notes: Massive frame, thick chest, beard. Died after returning from Yeller Quarry expedition. Final days marked by growling and cursing at neighbors.

name: Yasho Krent
notes: Female. Called a towering intellect. Had disciples and money. Sharp tongue in debates.

name: Vagabu Olt
notes: Wandering map-sketcher. Travels in a pickbox cart. Not a proper scholar by his own admission. Chronicler of the Grigsu circle.

name: Boffa Trent
notes: Member of the Grigsu-Yasho circle. Known for lengthy treatises on creature classification.

name: Mink Pavar
notes: Historian and archivist. Nursed resentment toward Grigsu after a kachot game dispute in 886. Later suspected of manuscript forgery.

name: Fibon Arrel
notes: Inventor of the binary world puzzle. Lived alone in Mirado. Believed words are like pebbles, not drops of water.

name: Eulr Voss
notes: The great thinker of Mirado. Codified the water-school position. Famous for saying words dissolve into the seventy pools.

name: Dannkit Rosh
notes: Stonebreaker and part-linguist from Grigsu's village. Nearly deaf from hammering. Lost wife and children. Got Grigsu to talk in his final days.

name: Colonel Viragu
notes: Military commander. Sieging Mirado for 15-20 years. Connected to Yeller. Has largely stopped communicating with anyone but Fyncho.

name: Fyncho Delt
notes: Lieutenant to Colonel Viragu. Only person the Colonel still speaks to. Loyalty is ambiguous.

name: Jorkin Mast
notes: Legendary figure. Subject of the paradox: if we discover Jorkin did not build the tower of Mirado, who is Jorkin?

name: Hesta Vorn
notes: Leading taxonomist of Yeller Quarry creatures. Trained under Boffa. Meticulous field notes.

name: Pollux Dann
notes: Taxonomist. Died during the Ninth Expedition after encountering a stakdur in the lower marshes.

name: Renna Caw
notes: Female. Applied water-school philosophy to taxonomy, arguing creature categories dissolve into one another.

name: Tomas Grell
notes: Elder cartographer. Trained Vagabu in map-sketching. Known for his maps of the Dens border regions.

name: Senna Grell
notes: Daughter of Tomas Grell. Continued his cartographic work. Specialized in Yeller Quarry route mapping.

name: Oric Valdun
notes: Legal scholar specializing in expedition contracts and archivist licensing law.

name: Pella Valdun
notes: Daughter of Oric. Continued his legal scholarship. Wrote extensively on family tree authentication.

name: Hamund Bress
notes: Northern philosopher. Stone-school adherent. Corresponded with Grigsu. Believed words could be frozen in cold climates.

name: Vera Losh
notes: Female. Student of Eulr. Extended water-school theory to include the concept of word-evaporation.

name: Kell Sundar
notes: Follower of Fibon. Applied pebble theory to the study of Mirado's seventy pools. Controversial figure.

name: Mara Yent
notes: Female. Historian of the Dens conquest. Student of Mink. Later discovered evidence of Mink's forgeries, but died before publishing.

name: Donal Crest
notes: Historian focusing on Capital political history. Documented the Senate's relationship with expeditions.

name: Wen Torval
notes: Quarry-born taxonomist. Deep knowledge of creature habitats. Killed during the Fifth Expedition, devoured by a stakdur.

name: Jara Torval
notes: Sister of Wen. Continued his work after his death. Applied stone-school thinking to creature naming conventions.

name: Oben Marsh
notes: Late stone-school adherent. Attempted to reconcile Grigsu's views with empirical observation. Only partially successful.

name: Callis Fenn
notes: Literalist philosopher. Argued all sides of a symbol must be visible at once. Disappeared during a solo expedition to the Dens border.

name: Roth Fenn
notes: Brother of Callis. Continued literalist work after his brother's disappearance. Less radical in his claims.

name: Nessa Bright
notes: Female. Third-generation water-school. Wrote the definitive refutation of stone-school philosophy, though some found it uncharitable.

name: Gareth Poll
notes: Modern cartographer. Studied under Vagabu. Known for his detailed maps of Dead River region.

name: Tam Whistle
notes: Poet and songwriter. Applied stone-school thinking to verse, believing poems are assemblages of word-stones.

name: Lira Canto
notes: Female. Poet. Water-school adherent. Famous for poems about dissolution and forgetting. Rival of Tam Whistle.

name: Venn Horak
notes: Aging scavenger living in the Quarry. One of four people who know something of Yeller. No known formal name. Called simply The Scavenger.

name: The Inventor
notes: Inventor wanderer from the North. One of four who know Yeller. Travels in a rolling vehicle of hide and bones. Makes maps and games, including a roving letters pattern game.

name: Pell Sontar
notes: Historian attached to the Ninth Expedition. Detailed chronicler. Died alongside Pollux Dann in the stakdur encounter.

name: Hork Staven
notes: Legal scholar. Specialized in Yeller Quarry family tree disputes. Often called as expert witness in lineage cases.

name: Denna Vox
notes: Female. Late pebble-school adherent. Attempted to revive Fibon's theories in the Capital, with limited success.

name: Cort Madden
notes: Natural philosopher. Generalist. Known for synthesizing creature taxonomy with geographical survey data.

name: Renna Gast
notes: Female. Early stone-school thinker from Grigsu's village. Codified the practice of casting stones after conversation. Dannkit's teacher.

name: Ulla Vant
notes: Female. Late Mirado water-school. Wrote on the relationship between the seventy pools and the dissolution of meaning.
